name: Antoine AllanoreProfessor
title: Professor
top_publications: What we didSubjected oxides of rare-earth and other important metals to a chemical process called sulfidation. We discovered process parameters to separate metals by having them form new, easily recovered chemicals.

Why we did itTraditional metal extraction methods involve liquid separation, which requires extra steps and materials to dissolve compounds and remove the elements as precipitates. The processes are resource- and time-intensive.

Why it mattersThis method of metallic elements extraction could be 65% to 95% cheaper than traditional liquid-based methods and could likely decrease greenhouse gas emissions by 60% to 90%. “Green” batteries and other sustainability initiatives depend on rare-earth and other key metals. Faster, more

name: Polina AnikeevaDepartment Head
title: Department Head
top_publications: What we didDeveloped an approach to deliver light and drugs on demand through a fiber and applied it to control behavior in mice. The experiment paves the way for future clinical applications of photopharmacology, which involves photosensitive molecules that upon illumination bind to receptors to en

Why we did itTo be applicable in vivo and eventually in clinic, photopharmacology needs minimally invasive hardware that can deliver light and drugs simultaneously to the target area. Such a device, especially one suitable for implantation deep in the body, has been lacking.
Why it mattersTargeting therapeutic drugs to a specific body tissue and activating it only as needed could eliminate unwanted side effects from medication taken orally or intravenously.

name: Geoffrey S.D. BeachProfessor
title: Professor
top_publications: What we didUsed a small, externally applied voltage to manipulate the magnetic properties of ferrimagnetic materials without attendant structural damage.

Why we did itConventional data storage devices are limited by the unchangeable magnetic properties of ferromagnetic materials. Ferrimagnetic materials—with ani—dorespond to external forces. If we can switch the orientation of these magnets by 180 degrees, we can pack more data into a given space. Bu
Why it mattersGetting more data into less space could enable faster data storage, smaller sensors, and more efficient use of scarce raw materials.

name: W. Craig CarterProfessor
title: Professor
top_publications: What we didShowed how metal filaments called dendrites form in solid-state batteries, and how their damaging effects can be reduced or averted altogether. Dendrites are one of the causes of premature failure of rechargeable batteries.

Why we did itOne way to a safer and lightweight lithium-ion battery is replacing the flammable liquid electrolyte with a thin layer of ceramic solid and one of the electrodes with solid lithium metal. Unfortunately, doing so leads to battery failure by promoting the formation of dendrites at the met
Why it mattersLearning how rechargeable batteries fail can increase their utility, a key aspect of sustainability initiatives.

name: Michael J. CimaProfessor
title: Professor
top_publications: What we didDeveloped a noninvasive diagnostic tool to detect fatty liver disease and liver fibrosis using nuclear magnetic resonance. We calculated the rate of water diffusion through liver cells by tracking magnetization changes of hydrogen in water. Low water diffusivity indicates that fatty liver

Why we did itThere’s a lack of low-cost noninvasive tools for following the progression of fatty liver disease to fibrosis, cirrhosis, and eventual failure. Fibrosis is usually diagnosed through an invasive biopsy only when patients present with symptoms.
Why it mattersDiagnosing liver damage earlier can help prevent organ failure, aid drug development efforts, and evaluate human livers for transplant potential.

name: Yoel FinkProfessor
title: Professor
top_publications: What we didDeveloped a rechargeable lithium-ion battery in the form of a self-contained ultra-long fiber that’s weavable and washable. The test produced the world’s longest flexible and waterproof fiber battery, at 140 meters long.

Why we did itFibers are bendable and can therefore produce novel-shaped electronic devices. But their small diameters and high aspect ratios mean fibers must be extremely long to meet the energy demands of portable electronic systems.
Why it mattersHaving no upper limit to fiber length opens a range of applications. The rechargeable battery can be woven to power wearable electronics and small robots.

name: Rodrigo FreitasAssistant Professor
title: Professor
top_publications: What we didEmployed machine learning methods and simulations to understand the role of the liquid in the solidification process.

Why we did itSolidification is the process by which crystals form, usually when a liquid freezes solid (water to ice). Most solidification studies have focused on structure of the crystallite. Considerably less is understood about the role of the liquid’s structure.

Why it mattersSolidification drives many crucial industrial applications, including the manufacture of semiconductor wafers. Understanding the process will enable researchers to control crystal growth and, ultimately, the final properties of the materials used to manufacture products.

name: Lorna J. GibsonProfessor
title: Professor
top_publications: What we didDevised an alternative approach to test the mechanical properties of the various tissues in bamboo. The new method involves enlarging the tissues’ microstructure into 3-D printed models so tests can be conducted more effectively.

Why we did itTo model bamboo, we needed to know if its spongy parenchyma tissue behaves like a honeycomb or a foam, as their properties depend on density in different ways. Since it’s difficult to cut out samples of parenchyma tissue, we 3-D printed larger-size replica structures of different densit

Why it mattersBecause bamboo is lightweight and sustainable, there’s growing interest in its use in construction. Understanding the mechanical properties of various kinds of bamboo is key in developing safe and reliable products.

name: Rafael Gómez-BombarelliAssociate Professor
title: Professor
top_publications: What we didDiscovered a better way of custom-designing zeolites, porous minerals that can trap unwanted molecules from gases or liquids.

Why we did itZeolites trap molecules—of carbon, for example, or hydrogen—using pores of the exact shape and size as the target. Customizing zeolites involves adding a “templating” molecule, which dictates the exact size and shape of the pores in the final product. Figuring out the template for speci
Why it mattersCustom zeolites have a variety of potential uses, including decarbonization. Synthesizing zeolites reliably and cheaply will speed their adoption in such applications.

name: Jeffrey GrossmanProfessor
title: Professor
top_publications: What we didAchieved substantial cooling capacity by controlling the effects of evaporative cooling, radiation, and thermal transport. Even in high-humidity areas, the process works without electricity and needs very little water.
Why we did itTraditional passive cooling relies on only evaporation, where water is consumed quickly. The process is not sustainable and not very effective in areas with high humidity either.

Why it mattersAs climate change accelerates, the poorest and hardest-hit regions of the world need to access cooling. This necessitates a system that will work effectively with zero or minimal dependence on electricity and water.

name: Aristide GumyusengeAssistant Professor
title: Professor
top_publications: What we didSynthesized a new category of polymers that can be used to produce more long-lasting and intelligent wearable devices. The materials efficiently convert ion-based signals from hydrated environments—for example, biological tissue—to electron-based signals that can easily be read through de

Why we did itToday’s wearables are somewhat limited in their electronic performance because they waste a lot of energy sampling biological signals—like insulin from sweat, for example. We need to optimize wearables’ sampling efficiencywithoutcompromising electronic performance.
Why it mattersWearables are becoming crucial in long-term health monitoring, so they need to be long-lasting, easy to manufacture at scale, and more seamlessly integrate with body functions.

name: Juejun HuProfessor
title: Professor
top_publications: What we didProved that you don’t need mechanical movement to change the focus of a lens. Instead, a transparent “metalens” changes the way it interacts with infrared light when it undergoes heat-based phase transformation. To see objects far and near, one would simply heat the material using microhe

Why we did itTraditional glass-based optical lenses need mechanical motion to focus on objects. The knobs or other components used for this purpose add unwanted bulk to imaging instruments and are prone to wear and tear.
Why it mattersBecause it doesn’t require bulky mechanical elements, the metalens may enable miniature and lighter imaging systems in a variety of devices—from drones to night-vision goggles.

name: Rafael JaramilloAssociate Professor
title: Professor
top_publications: What we didCreated high-quality thin films of a new family of semiconductors: chalcogenide perovskites. The films comprise barium, zirconium, and sulfur in a particular structure called perovskite. We used a technique called molecular beam epitaxy to give atomic-level control over crystal growth whi

Why we did itGiven the broad range of applications for semiconductors, the more choices there are, the better. Chalcogenide perovskites were first developed, in very small quantities, in the 1950s, but their potential as semiconductors has only recently come to light.
Why it mattersThe new semiconductors are ultrastable and made with inexpensive, nontoxic raw materials. They could potentially find use in solar cells and lighting.

name: James M. LeBeauProfessor
title: Professor
top_publications: What we didExtended the commercial viability of fuel cells and improved original performance despite long-term degradation of the metal oxide components. We recovered poisoned metal oxide surfaces by systematically controlling their acidity.

Why we did itTraditional approaches to fuel cell life focus on limiting exposure to degradation agents. We offer an effective alternative that breathes new life into cells that might otherwise be discarded for good.

Why it mattersExtending the lifetime of solid oxide fuel cells lowers the effective cost of conversion of hydrogen or other chemical fuels to electricity. It thereby facilitates power generation needed for a clean-energy future.

name: Ju LiProfessor
title: Professor
top_publications: What we didDeveloped programmable resistors, or artificial synapses—devices that can be used to build analog deep learning processors. Compatible with silicon fabrication techniques, these artificial synapses increase the speed and reduce the energy needed to train neural network models.

Why we did itDeep learning, a subset of artificial intelligence (AI), is key for successful automation, facilitating many analytical and computational tasks without human intervention. But training these models using current computers is associated with unsustainably high energy demand. Low-energy a

Why it mattersDeep learning processors that can execute computations fast while using much less energy can satisfy the growing need for AI while still meeting sustainability goals. Faster training of neural networks means faster deployment of deep learning use cases like fraud detection and medical

name: Gregory B. OlsonProfessor of the Practice
title: Professor
top_publications: What we didCreated a category of shape-memory materials from ceramics that can operate at higher temperatures without sustaining much damage.

Why we did itShape-memory materials function as actuators, changing shape as a reaction to external stimuli such as heat. Ductile metals, popular materials in this category, withstand damage well. But their utility is limited as they do not function well at high temperatures.

Why it mattersMany applications, such as jet engine operations, require actuators that can withstand the stress generated by high heat. Having a single solid-state ceramic material can help in such situations. Ceramic actuators can potentially also work in microscale applications like lab-on-a-chip

name: C. Cem TasanAssociate Professor
title: Professor
top_publications: What we didDiscovered why stainless-steel blades lose their sharpness over time. We found that a single strand of hair can cause the blade to chip. These degradations are more likely to happen if the blade’s microstructure is not uniform or if the blade cuts hair at an angle.
Why we did itTo find out why blades quickly get dull even when they interact with much softer material, like human hair.

Why it mattersUnderstanding the reasons for failure of materials provides us guidelines for improving them. In this case, making blades of more homogeneous microstructures will likely make them chip-resistant and last longer.

name: Carl V. ThompsonProfessor
title: Professor
top_publications: What we didStudied the phase transitions that occur when lithium ions are introduced into silicon thin films (such “lithiation” controls the performance of silicon-based energy storage materials).

Why we did itLithiation-based phase transformations in silicon allow high levels of energy storage, but they can also cause degradation and failure of batteries. Studying how these changes occur is important to prevent failure and improve reliability and performance.

Why it mattersReliable high-performance thin film batteries can be used in very small and inexpensive self-powered sensors for applications that range from monitoring human health to monitoring the health of the planet.

name: Harry L. TullerProfessor
title: Professor
top_publications: What we didExtended the commercial viability of fuel cells and improved original performance despite long-term degradation of the metal oxide components. We recovered poisoned metal oxide surfaces by systematically controlling their acidity.

Why we did itTraditional approaches to fuel cell life focus on limiting exposure to degradation agents. We offer an effective alternative that breathes new life into cells that might otherwise be discarded for good.

Why it mattersExtending the lifetime of solid oxide fuel cells lowers the effective cost of conversion of hydrogen or other chemical fuels to electricity. It thereby facilitates power generation needed for a clean-energy future.

name: Bilge YildizProfessor
title: Professor
top_publications: What we didDeveloped programmable resistors, or artificial synapses—devices that can be used to build analog deep learning processors. Compatible with silicon fabrication techniques, these artificial synapses increase the speed and reduce the energy needed to train neural network models.

Why we did itDeep learning, a subset of artificial intelligence (AI), is key for successful automation, facilitating many analytical and computational tasks without human intervention. But training these models using current computers is associated with unsustainably high energy demand. Low-energy a

Why it mattersDeep learning processors that can execute computations fast while using much less energy can satisfy the growing need for AI while still meeting sustainability goals. Faster training of neural networks means faster deployment of deep learning use cases like fraud detection and medical

name: Christopher SchuhVisiting Professor
title: Professor
top_publications: What we didCreated a category of shape-memory materials from ceramics that can operate at higher temperatures without sustaining much damage.

Why we did itShape-memory materials function as actuators, changing shape as a reaction to external stimuli such as heat. Ductile metals, popular materials in this category, withstand damage well. But their utility is limited as they do not function well at high temperatures.

Why it mattersMany applications, such as jet engine operations, require actuators that can withstand the stress generated by high heat. Having a single solid-state ceramic material can help in such situations. Ceramic actuators can potentially also work in microscale applications like lab-on-a-chip
